responses.content_en: This looks like a cyst. Needs incision and drainage of contents. However, I need to know some details. Since when it was present, does it exude some pus or sebaceous material?

You have ingrown hairs. That is normal. They can be caused by any trauma to the area. The most important thing is to keep the area clean and dry. There are several things you can do to help the area heal:
- Donâ€™t scratch the area. This will only make it worse.
- Apply a topical steroid cream for a week to help the area heal.

This looks good and you are most likely fine to continue doing nothing. The spot is most likely to be found on lighter skinned individuals with a history of sun exposure. If it is new or changing then it may require a biopsy to make sure it's not a melanoma.

Milia are small cysts that contain keratin (the skin protein). They can appear for many reasons, such as infections, injuries, or irritants. Milia do not need to be treated unless they are a cause for concern for the patient. They often clear up by themselves within a few months. Where possible, further trauma should be minimized to reduce the development of new lesions. The lesion may be de-roofed using a sterile needle or blade and the contents squeezed or pricked out.
They may be destroyed using diathermy and curettage, or cryotherapy.

It is a case of lymphatic malformation, a type of vascular naevus or birthmark due to malformed and dilated lymphatic vessels. Lymphangioma circumscriptum is benign (non-cancerous) and usually requires no treatment. Antibiotics may be given if secondary infection occurs (rare). If necessary it may be removed surgically, by dermabrasion or by laser. They have a tendency to recur after treatment.

This is a case of varicella, a dermatological disease also known as chickenpox. It is a viral infection that affects the skin, causing redness, itching, and sometimes blisters. It is highly contagious and is mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when someone scratches their skin and then touches another area of the body. You are at higher risk of varicella if you have never had it, are allergic to bee venom, or have a weakened immune system. There is no cure for varicella, but you can reduce the risk of complications by getting vaccinated and treating the symptoms.

This looks like it could be tinea versicolor. It is a fungal infection and is more common in hot, humid climates. It will often clear up on its own in a few weeks, but sometimes it can persist and cause skin damage.

It is a case of keratosis pilaris which is a harmless skin condition that causes dry, rough patches and tiny bumps, often on the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks. Worsening occurs when seasonal changes cause low humidity and dry skin you can treat it with moisturizers and prescription creams to help improve how the skin looks. Creams to remove dead skin cells like creams containing alpha hydroxy acid, lactic acid, salicylic acid, or urea help loosen and remove dead skin cells. They also moisturize and soften dry skin. For best results, apply your moisturizer after every shower or bath, within 5 minutes of getting out of the bath or shower, while your skin is still damp. At least 2 or 3 times a day, gently massaging it into the skin. You can also use topical retinoid creams to help unclog follicles and promote cell turnover. Some patients may need to apply a corticosteroid to the areas with keratosis pilaris. This medicine helps soften the bumps and reduce redness. Lasers may work when moisturizers and medicine fail. Using medicated cream regularly may improve how the skin looks. But if you stop, the condition returns. And even with treatment, keratosis pilaris might last for years.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy, or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If persistent, it is recommended to consult your dermatologist. It is also worth mentioning the duration of the lesion may rise Becker's nevus, a non-cancerous large brown birthmark occurring mostly in males, as a possible diagnosis.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

This is temporary and can be caused by itching. It is not clear if there is any underlying dermatitis. The wrinkles can be caused by pressure from objects on the hands or just regular muscle contraction. The wrinkles can also be caused by smoking, so if you smoke, the wrinkles may be more severe.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.
This is hand eczema. Use mild handwash and apply petroleum jelly multiple times daily. Keep hand dry.

Most probably it is a case of hormonal acne. Acne is largely a hormonal condition thatâ€™s driven by androgen hormones (testosterone). This typically becomes active during teenage and young adult years. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions, that are applied to the skin. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

This is not eczema. This is contact dermatitis. It can be due to contact with an irritant or an allergen. Use mild soap and moisturizer at regular intervals. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can give a painkiller and antihistamine on a PRN basis. Avoid direct contact with food items.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin. For example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If persistent, it is recommended to consult your dermatologist. It is also worth mentioning the duration of the lesion may rise Becker's nevus, a non-cancerous large brown birthmark occurring mostly in males, as a possible diagnosis.

This is eczema. It is an allergic reaction to something. Avoid contact with any irritants, jewellery, perfume, and deodorant. Avoid scratching. Apply moisturiser and sunscreen. I am adding a cream. Apply the cream twice daily until it heals. You can take antihistamine on a PRN basis.

This is a case of insect bite reaction which is a self limiting immunological reaction to the bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are most often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

It is a case of insect bite reaction which is a self limiting immunological reaction to the bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are most often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

I need to know whether there was any history of trauma, and if it has increased in size. It can be due to trauma or excessive sun exposure. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturizer and sunscreen.
This looks like it could be a contact dermatitis of the nail. I would recommend a topical steroid and regular moisturization with vaseline to help the nail heal.

You have facial muscle atrophy which is causing the wrinkles in your forehead. This is not a skin condition in itself and you do not need to do anything unless the muscle atrophy is severe. However, if the muscle atrophy is severe and persistent, you may consider a facelift or other surgical intervention.

It is a case of folliculitis. Acneiform eruptions on the face and neck are described as folliculitis, which may be due to infection, obstruction, or unknown irritant factors. Time course, distribution and appearance may be helpful in making a more accurate diagnosis. The acneiform eruptions may be caused by hormonal and metabolic abnormalities, drug reactions, and genetic disorders. While many things can damage your hair follicles, the following are also common causes of folliculitis hot tub (improperly maintained), shaving, plucking, or waxing, tight clothing or equipment, medication applied to the skin, such as coal tar, medication you take, or weight gain. Apply a warm compress at least 3 to 4 times a day. Leave the compress on your skin for 15 to 20 minutes each time. When shaving, plucking, or waxing causes the infection, youâ€™ll want to stop doing these things for 30 days. Wear loose clothing when itâ€™s hot and humid. Use well-maintained hot tubs. Wash your bathing suit or wetsuit after each use and let it dry. The treatment of acneiform eruptions depends on the cause. In most cases, if the cause is an organism or a drug, then the exposure should be discontinued. Most patients recover within a few weeks. For any residual lesions, treatments that have been used to treat acneiform eruptions include laser ablation, excision, topical or oral antibiotics, drug withdrawal, or the use of topical or oral retinoids. If the cause is a fungal infection like Pityrosporum folliculitis, then the use of topical antifungal agents can be helpful such as ciclopirox, econazole, and ketoconazole.

This is eczema. Use mild handwash and apply petroleum jelly multiple times daily. Keep hand in lukewarm water for 10 mins, then dry and apply cream which I have added. Cream is to be used twice daily for 3 weeks. Avoid irritants like detergents, vegetable juices, and hand sanitizer.

It is a case of nevus or mole on the scalp. Nevus is not the same as mole. Nevus can include nevus of the scalp, which is also called nevus on the scalp. Nevus of the scalp is usually described as simple nevus or simple neuroma. It is not clear if this is nevus of the scalp or if it has been there for some time. If it is new and not changing, then you should consider seeing your doctor to make sure there is not something more serious going on.

It is a case of alopecia areata. It is a type of autoimmune disorder. Stress will aggravate it. Donâ€™t skip your meals. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks. Apply moisturizer. Wear a hat.
This is eczema. Use mild soap and moisturizer. Apply sunscreen. Avoid irritants. Wear cotton clothes.

This does look like it is probably a mole. If it is not changing, growing, or bleeding then it is most likely okay to leave. However, if it is doing any of those things then consider seeing your doctor for a possible biopsy.

This looks like eczema. Since it's on the face and not just on the chest, it could also be a reaction to something you used, such as a soap or a lotion. Try to identify what it is so you can treat it better.
This is likely a case of post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation, also known as hypermelanosis. It will gradually fade if you wear sunscreen and avoid additional trauma to the area.

It is a case of contact dermatitis. It is a common condition that arises due to contact with an irritant. People with contact dermatitis experience redness and itching of the skin. They may have dry skin. The skin barrier is broken. This can happen due to direct contact with a substance or irritant, such as soap, detergents, dyes, and fragrances, or it can happen due to excessive bathing or handwashing. Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day when you have dry skin. Apply moisturizer when your skin is damp after a bath or shower. Apply topical medications to the skin like topical hydrocortisone cream. Take oral medications like anti inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids to reduce itchiness and swelling. Choose skin care moisturizers that are hypoallergenic, fragrance and dye free, gentle or for sensitive skin, contain petroleum jelly or mineral oil, donâ€™t include preservatives or stabilizers, and have lipids and ceramides to improve your skinâ€™s barrier. Avoid irritants.
This is an abrasion after some trauma. It is not infected. However, I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 10 days. Apply moisturiser and sunscreen.
You have peeling feet. Apply moisturizer. Keep your feet dry. Avoid friction from shoes and socks.

You need to see a dermatologist for dermoscopic examination of this lesion and skin biopsy if needed. The dermoscopic examination is a useful adjunct for pigmented lesions to help identify worrisome pigment patterns. Regular self-examinations of your skin will help you detect a difference in a mole over time. An easy way to remember how to check your skin is to use the ABCDE technique to identify changes.
Asymmetry - Each half of the mole is a different shape
Border - Look for spreading or irregular edges
Colour - A recent change or blotchy spots with many colours
Diameter - spots are getting bigger 
Evolving - Changing or growing in size, shape or thickness. If you noticed any change consulting your dermatologist is recommended.

This is a case of cystic acne. It is a common condition that occurs when hair follicles and sebaceous glands become blocked with oil, bacteria, and dead skin cells. This buildup can cause a range of symptoms including redness, swelling, and pimples. There are many different types of acne and different treatments for them. Creams and lotions containing benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, or antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin are used to treat acne. Oral antibiotics can cause oral acne. You can also use topical retinoids, topical antibiotics, or oral retinoids.

The wound is on the calf. It is important to clean the wound and apply topical antibiotics twice daily for 2 weeks. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can take painkillers on an as needed basis.
I need to know whether your hand itches. If it itches you need to apply moisturizer and sunscreen. Keep your hands and face moisturized. Apply the cream which i have added twice daily for 2 weeks.

It is a case of Cherry angioma, a benign vascular skin lesion. An angioma is due to proliferating endothelial cells; these are the cells that line the inside of a blood vessel. It is usually diagnosed clinically and investigation is not necessary for the majority of lesions. Cherry angiomas are harmless, so do not have to be treated. If desired for cosmetic reasons, Cryotherapy, Electrosurgery, or Vascular laser can be used.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of urticaria, a self-limiting immunological reaction to drugs, food, bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Avoid triggers like certain types of food (eggs, peanuts) and some medications. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams, and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.
This does look like postacne. It is important to keep the area clean and avoid irritants. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturizer and sunscreen. Avoid scratching.

This looks like it could be a contact dermatitis of the nail. You should look at any products you're using around your nail including soap, hand sanitizer, and nail polish. It will likely get better if you stop using the product and let the nail grow out. You could also try a topical steroid to help it heal faster.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.
